unnormalised: The landscape of school examinations in India is constantly evolving, shaped by changing pedagogical approaches and national education policies. As students gear up for crucial assessments like the CBSE Class 10 and 12 exams, understanding the nuances of these evaluations is paramount. The emphasis has shifted from rote learning to a more holistic assessment of a student’s grasp of concepts and their ability to apply that knowledge in real-world scenarios.
normalised: The landscape of school examinations in India is constantly evolving, shaped by changing pedagogical approaches and national education policies. As students gear up for crucial assessments like the C-B-S-E Class ten and twelve exams, understanding the nuances of these evaluations is paramount. The emphasis has shifted from rote learning to a more holistic assessment of a student’s grasp of concepts and their ability to apply that knowledge in real world scenarios.

unnormalised: One significant change observed over the past decade is the increased weightage given to internal assessments. Schools like DPS, Modern School, and Kendriya Vidyalayas now incorporate projects, practical exams, and classroom participation into the final score. For example, in CBSE Class 10, internal assessments contribute 20 marks out of 100 in each subject. This approach aims to provide a more comprehensive picture of a student’s abilities, reducing the pressure associated with the final written examination.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the implementation of the Continuous and Comprehensive Evaluation (CCE) system, though debated, marked a significant shift towards regular assessments throughout the academic year. While CCE has undergone revisions, the core principle of ongoing evaluation remains central to the examination process. The National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 further emphasizes formative assessment and the use of technology in evaluations.

unnormalised: The competitive landscape surrounding entrance exams like JEE and NEET also influences school-level examinations. Students aiming for IIT or AIIMS often find themselves balancing school coursework with rigorous coaching for these competitive exams. This dual preparation sometimes leads to undue stress and a focus on scoring high marks rather than deep understanding. The cut-off for many engineering colleges often goes as high as 98% or even 99% and higher depending on the school board.

The cut off for many engineering colleges often goes as high as ninety eight percent or even ninety nine percent and higher depending on the school board.

unnormalised: In addition to the academic aspects, the psychological well-being of students during examination periods is receiving increased attention. Counseling services, stress management workshops, and relaxation techniques are being offered in many schools to help students cope with exam-related anxiety. Parents are also encouraged to play a supportive role, fostering a healthy and encouraging environment. Many schools provide access to a school counselor who can help students in times of crises.

unnormalised: The use of technology in examination management is also gaining traction. Online platforms for conducting internal assessments, digital mark sheets, and secure online portals for accessing results are becoming increasingly common. This technological integration enhances efficiency, transparency, and accessibility. Many schools have switched to platforms like Google Classroom and Microsoft Teams to conduct exams in order to save money, time and resources.

unnormalised: Looking ahead, the future of school examinations in India is likely to be characterized by a continued emphasis on holistic assessment, competency-based education, and the integration of technology. The focus will be on nurturing critical thinking, problem-solving skills, and creativity, preparing students for the challenges and opportunities of the 21st century. Exams like the CBSE board exams due on 15/02/2025 will likely look much different as new regulations and educational changes come into play.
